bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, September 3, [1941]

div1.p: Truby describes the interior of the living quarters at Camp Lazear and the problems they had with toads entering through the roof.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, September 3, [1941]
div1.p:
After mailing the other
photos & letters to you I
found I had left out
those inclosed herwith.
They are most interesting
and I have enjoyed seeing
them. The interior of the
old shack seems to have been
whitewashed. The ceiling is
interesting and was evidently
copied by Reed from the ceiling
in our own quarters (Bldg 108)
The difference is that in our
building the center section (top)
was open and the hot air could
get out through the cowls.
The space between the ceiling
& iron roof was at least a foot
in our quarters and it was
a great help in disipating
the heat from the hot roof acted
just as a tent fly does over a tent
in the hot sun. Tree toads were
& I think this ceiling was suggested by the tent fly-
very numerous and they would
get up to the open space in
the ceiling and at night we
would hear them plop on
the floor with their moist
bellies. In the morning we
would find them in our water
pails with their heads out of
water. Those of us who did not
like to use mosquito bars did
use them to prevent the frogs
from landing in their faces
at night. This is true. Ask
Pinto sometime if he remembers
it. A good sized toad would
awaken the soundest sleeper
with the noise- They amused
Reed but he never enjoyed
having them in his water pail-

We had no running water
except in the bath house.

This is a little incident
which will interest you and
also will pay for my neglect
in forgetting the photos
